trial_identification.studytitle: In vivo plaque calcium phosphate deposition from toothpaste
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Pilot trial invovling students at the University of Otago Wellington to determine the level of calcium phosphate mineral deposisted in dental plaque in vivo using a novel plaque mineralising toothpaste as a procedure to protect against dental caries.
trial_identification.secondaryid: TT50-8354(989) Standing Committee on Therapeutic Trials

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal oral and gastrointestinal development and function

interventions.interventions: Plaque mineralising toothpaste to be used twice daily (morning and evening) for 4 weeks
interventions.comparator: This trial involves only one treatment arm. Each participant has a 4 week standardisation period using a commercially available toothpaste followed by a 4 week treatment period using the trial toothpaste. All participants will receive the same treatment for 4 weeks.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Increased calcium phosphate deposition in plaque assessed by measuring levels of calcium, phosphate, fluoride and protein in the dental plaque.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Initial assessment of the primary outcome parameters will be at baseline, then reassessed at week 4 after the 4 week standardisation period, and then again at week 8 following 4 week treatment with the plaque mineralising toothpaste.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Dental plaque properties: the ability of dental plaque to cause a sucrose-induced pH decrease assessed using a commercially available kit (GC Corp), and microorganism composition analysed in the laboratory using Checkerboard deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) hybridisation.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Initial assessment of secondary outcome parameters will be made at week 0 (baseline), then reassessed at week 4 after the 4 week standardisation period, and then again at week 8 following 4 week treatment with the plaque mineralising toothpaste.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Saliva properties: pH, buffer capacity, and Streptococcus mutans (S. mutans), assessed using a commercially available kit (GC Corp), and microorganism composition analysed in the laboratory using Checkerboard deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) hybridisation.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Initial assessment at week 0 (baseline), then reassessed at week 4 and at week 8.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Association of prior oral and general health assessed using questionnaires, plus dental clinical measurements of gingivitis, plaque index, caries history as decayed-missing-filled teeth, and periodontal pocket depth.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Initial assessment at week 0 (baseline), then reassessed at week 4 and at week 8.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Effects of treatment on clinically-assessed gingivitis and calculus formation.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Initial assessment at week 0 (baseline), then reassessed at week 4 and at week 8.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Requirement to treat for periodontal disease or other immediate dental treatment needed. History of rheumatic heart disease/fever

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Current approaches to counter dental caries are mainly limited to fluoride treatments which include water fluoridation, fluoridated toothpastes, and professionally applied topical fluoride preparations. The effectiveness of fluoride is limited as almost half the NZ population has an unfluoridated water supply, and toothpaste use is infrequent for many people. New approaches and interventions are needed. The overall aim of our research is to counter caries development by depositing a tooth-like mineral into dental plaque by using a plaque-mineralising toothpaste containing the tooth minerals, calcium and phosphate. The aim is to protect the tooth mineral from acid dissolution, enhance the effectiveness of remineralization induced by fluoride (which will also be supplied in the toothpaste), and modify the plaque microbial composition. This trial is designed to evaluate the efficacy of the plaque mineralising toothpaste by determining the levels of mineral deposited in dental plaque in vivo after its use over a four week period. This study is based on laboratory-based findings in our previous studies.
